_accidents.OtherReleaseSource: compressed gas cylinders on DOT trailer

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Tyler Welder's Supply (TWS) has prepared this initial Risk Management Plan (RMP) for its compressed gas cylinder filling facility in Tyler, Texas in accordance with 40 CFR Part 68 of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program. The Tyler facility will be considered as a RMP Program 3 facility beginning in late September 2017 because the company intends to increase the quantities of acetylene and propylene stored on the site to above 10,000 pounds each.  The company does not manufacture acetylene or propylene and prior to submittal of this RMP, the onsite inventory was carefully managed to ensure that the site did not exceed a threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds of either product at any time.   



The following activities were conducted in support of the RMP, in accordance with EPA RMP guidance:

?    A risk and gap assessment of the current and future operations at the site was conducted.

?    The elements of a Program Level 3 RMP plan were prepared.

?    A new health, safety, and environmental management system, to include the elements required by OSHA's PSM and EPA's RMP programs, was developed for the site 

        operations.

?    The Offsite Consequence Analysis was conducted using the RMP*Comp model. 

?    The seismic analysis for the affected systems was reviewed for changes to the system, and changes to the building codes that may impact affected systems.

?    The Process Hazards Analysis (PHA) for the facility was conducted using a combination What If/Checklist analysis method.

?    TWS prepared a new RMP registration submittal to reflect the changes to the site operations, specifically increases in the quantities of acetylene and 

        propylene stored on the premises.



ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICY

It is the policy of Tyler Welder's Supply management to implement the requirements of this RMP. This RMP was developed in accordance with the RMP regulations. The objective of this program is to minimize the r

isk of a release of acetylene and propylene, regulated chemicals, and, if a release occurs, to minimize the potential impact to employees, the public, and the environment. This objective will be accomplished by utilizing equipment designed for safe operation; utilizing good operating procedures; providing appropriate training to affected employees; and by coordinating response activities, as necessary, with the off-site emergency response providers. TWS management is committed to providing the resources necessary to implement this policy.



DESCRIPTION OF THE FACILITY AND AFFECTED PROCESS

The TWS facility located at 3539 Hwy 271 in Tyler, Texas receives bulk acetylene and propylene from various suppliers and in turn transfills individual cylinders of various sizes from manifolds connected to bulk cylinder trailers (acetylene) or bulk storage tanks (propylene).   TWS has the potential to store up to 35,000 pounds of acetylene and up to 30,000 pounds of propylene in bulk tanks and individual compressed gas cylinder at the facility at any given time.  



The acetylene is stored in DOT over the road trailers until is transferred to the acetylene cylinder fill lines.  The site has the capacity to store hundreds of empty, partially filled, and filled acetylene cylinders, ranging in size from MC to AC5.   The TWS facility receives bulk acetylene trailers from suppliers and in turn transfills individual acetylene cylinders of various sizes from a manifold connected to the bulk cylinder trailer.   The trailers received at TWS each contain a total of 90,000 cubic feet of acetylene stored in 200 individual cylinders at 250 psig and connected together to a common header on the trailer.  A cubic foot of acetylene weighs .07 pounds, resulting in a total of 6,300 pounds of product for each trailer if fully loaded.



The propylene is stored in four 1,000-gallon horizontal bulk tanks until it is transferred through a short common manifold to a single nearby fill station and scal

e.  The site has the capacity to store hundreds of empty, partially filled, and filled propylene cylinders, ranging in size from LP5 to HT.   A gallon of propylene weighs 8.62 pounds, resulting in a total of 7,310 pounds of product for each storage tank if the tanks are filled to 85% capacity.



Additional compressed gas and welding supply products are stored at the site prior to wholesale or retail sales.  The facility consists of 7 single-story buildings used for retail sales, offices, cylinder filling, warehousing, cylinder inspection and refurbishment, and other related operations.  Light commercial and residential development is present in the areas around the facility.



HAZARD ASSESSMENT

In accordance with the requirements for the Risk Management Plan, TWS has conducted an offsite consequence analysis to evaluate various emergency release scenarios.  TWS has the potential to store up to 35,000 pounds of acetylene and up to 30,000 pounds of propylene in bulk tanks and individual compressed gas cylinder at their facility at any given time.  



The acetylene is stored in DOT over the road trailers until is transferred to the acetylene cylinder fill lines.  The site has the capacity to store hundreds of empty, partially filled, and filled acetylene cylinders, ranging in size from MC to AC5.   The TWS facility receives bulk acetylene trailers from suppliers and in turn transfills individual acetylene cylinders of various sizes from a manifold connected to the bulk cylinder trailer.   The trailers received at TWS each contain a total of 90,000 cubic feet of acetylene stored in 200 individual cylinders at 250 psig and connected together to a common header on the trailer.  A cubic foot of acetylene weighs .07 pounds, resulting in a total of 6,300 pounds of product for each trailer if fully loaded.



The propylene is stored in four 1,000-gallon horizontal bulk tanks until it is transferred through a short common manifold to a single nearby fill station and scale.

The site has the capacity to store hundreds of empty, partially filled, and filled propylene cylinders, ranging in size from LP5 to HT.   A gallon of propylene weighs 8.62 pounds, resulting in a total of 7,310 pounds of product for each storage tank if the tanks are filled to 85% capacity.



Tyler Welders Supply uses all reasonable safety evaluations and training requirements to ensure the proper offloading, storage, and transfilling of acetylene and propylene.  In case of serious release beyond the ability of the facility's personnel to control and remediate, it is the company's policy to immediately notify the fire department by calling 911 and other parties in accordance with the Facility Emergency Response Plan.   



Acetylene Release Scenarios 

Tyler Welders Supply has modeled the worst-case release scenario for acetylene as a total release of one trailer load with an approximate weight of 6,300 pounds of acetylene to the atmosphere resulting in vapor cloud explosion.  Using an EPA approved model, RMP*Comp, the results of the offsite consequence analysis estimated the distance to the overpressure endpoint of 1 psi to be 1,056 feet or roughly 0.2 mile.   



Tyler Welders Supply has modeled the alternate worst-case release scenario as a total release of one bulk trailer load of acetylene with an approximate weight of 6,300 pounds of acetylene to the atmosphere with no explosion but with a flash fire.  Using an EPA approved model, RMP*Comp, the results of the offsite consequence analysis estimated the distance to the lower flammability limit to be 528 feet or roughly 0.1 mile.   



The Tyler Welders Supply facility in Tyler Texas is in a light industrial and commercial area with only moderate residential development nearby.   The 0.2 mile radius for the 1 psi overpressure endpoint value for the worst case scenario for acetylene does extend beyond the facility property line on all sides to the adjoining properties that are used for residential single family

housing, auto repair, logistics, and other retail operations.  The .1 mile radius flash fire endpoint value for the alternate worst case scenario also extends beyond the facility property line.  



Propylene Release Scenarios 

Tyler Welders Supply has modeled the worst-case release scenario for propylene as a total release of one storage tank of propylene with an approximate weight of 7,310 pounds of propylene resulting in a vapor cloud explosion.  Using an EPA approved model, RMP*Comp, the results of the offsite consequence analysis estimated the distance to the overpressure endpoint of 1 psi to be 1,056 feet or roughly 0.2 miles.  



Tyler Welders Supply has modeled the required alternate worst-case release scenario for propylene as a total release of one storage tank of propylene with an approximate weight of 7,310 pounds of propylene to the atmosphere with no explosion but with a flash fire.  Using an EPA approved model, RMP*Comp, the results of the offsite consequence analysis estimated the distance to the lower flammability limit to be less than 264 feet or roughly 0.05 mile.  



The Tyler Welders Supply facility in Tyler Texas is in a light industrial and commercial area with only moderate residential development nearby.   The 0.2 mile radius for the 1 psi overpressure endpoint value for the worst case scenario for acetylene does extend beyond the facility property line on all sides to the adjoining properties that are used for residential single family housing, auto repair, logistics, and other retail operations.  The 0.1 mile radius flash fire endpoint value for the alternate worst case scenario does extend beyond the facility property line.  



The facility has access restrictions to the public and visitors must obtain authorization before entering the facility and the access controlled perimeter encompassing the truck offloading rack, warehouses, and cylinder transfilling areas.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM



Process Safety Information

All of the documents assembled as part of TWS HSE Management System and Process Safety program are available for review by all employees in TWS administrative office and are incorporated into this RMP by reference. 

The equipment used in the cylinder transfilling process has been designed and engineered to the highest standards for this process. The materials of construction are compatible with acetylene and propylene. 



Process Hazard Analysis

In accordance with the requirements set forth in the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) rule, "Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals" (29 CFR 1910.119) and the EPA's Risk Management Program rule TWS conducted a Process Hazard Analysis to identify and address process related hazards involving transfilling of cylinders with acetylene and propylene.  

The methodology utilized for conducting the PHA used a systematic process to identify hazards in order to plan for, avoid, and mitigate their impacts.  For this project, PHA study facilitation was provided by IFO Group to assist a team of personnel from TWS in conducting an evaluation of the processes at the Tyler facility.    The PHA facilitator was familiar with the process and has been performing PHA facilitations since 1994.   

The potential risks identified by this PHA were connected to loss of primary containment during the acetylene and propylene delivery process and transfilling of cylinders.  The PHA Team reviewed five (5) nodes and identified five recommendations for consideration.    At this time, all other identified risks have been reduced to a level of acceptable risk with existing safeguards.



Operating Procedures

TWS has written operating procedures for the handling of acetylene and propylene in the cylinder transfilling process, covering the handling of these compressed gases from receipt onsite to the point where cylinders are filled are ready for distribution to end users.  



Training/Certification Programs

TWS has

a training program for operations, safety, emergency response, and maintenance to ensure that every employee has the skills to perform his or her job safely and effectively. 

Formal training is supplemented with informal instruction and discussion of safety issues during meetings conducted by site management. The employees participate in period evacuation and emergency drills. Training records are maintained in the permanent employee file.



Compliance Audits

The first three-year PSM / RMP compliance audit will be conducted in mid-2020 using an audit checklist. 



Incident Investigation

TWS will follow an established Incident Investigation procedure to determine the cause of any serious incidents and implement corrective action. Recordkeeping forms are provided with the Incident Investigation procedure. Completed forms will be kept on-file at the TWS administrative offices for at least five years.



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY 

Within the previous five years, there has been one accident on the site involving acetylene that resulted in significant onsite property damage.   There have been no incidents involving propylene.   



On Tuesday, June 13, 2017 at approximately 1315 CST, a DOT regulated tractor and acetylene cylinder trailer combination owned and operated by Praxair, arrived at the TWS facility located at 3539 Hwy 271 in Tyler, Texas.  The Praxair driver backed the trailer into the designated parking area and then dismounted his tractor in order to charge the cargo manifold in order to check for leaks before releasing the trailer to TWS.   During the arrival inspection, a fire involving the newly arrived trailer occurred and personnel at the facility contacted the local fire department to report the incident.  All personnel evacuated from the site to await the arrival of first responders.  The fire subsequently spread to two empty acetylene trailers and one trailer that contained approximately 2,200 pounds of acetylene.   The trailers were totally loss

es and the fire damaged some trees and other vegetation in the immediate area.   This incident occurred when threshold quantities of acetylene stored on the site were maintained below 10,000 pounds and the trailer involved in the initiating event was still under the control and custody of Praxair.   



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION

TWS has an "Emergency Action Plan" which details actions to be taken in the event of various emergencies. The EAP was last updated in September 2017. 



MANAGEMENT SYSTEM

The Vice President of TWS has overall responsibility for implementation of the RMP program and he will delegate individual tasks as necessary to fulfill the RMP requirements.  RMP program documents are maintained in the TWS administrative office.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

TWS has implemented the below actions as the implementation of this RMP has progressed. No other changes are planned at this time.

?    Erection of fire walls between each designated parking space for bulk acetylene storage trailers.
